stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on creating assets and implementing platforming mechanics for Course 11, an oil rig level inspired by Super Mario Sunshine's Rico Harbor. Key activities included debugging a major zipline regression, implementing and iterating on a new lighting system, changing the level's color palette based on feedback, and reviewing a new Bowser animation from Zeina. The stream also included a test on N64 hardware which revealed graphical bugs.

development_findings.summary: Inspired by Mario Odyssey, Kaze implemented a new camera-based light source to brighten Mario and other moving objects, improving scene readability but also creating new bugs with static level lighting.
development_findings.quote: I was watching Mario Odyssey footage... Basically, I added the light coming from the camera back. So now all the moving objects are kind of colored in by the camera... which makes the whole game look a lot brighter.

development_findings.summary: The massive performance demands of the 'Wario's Wildlife World' (The Zoo) level were the primary motivation for Kaze to begin his extensive engine optimization work on the SM64 decompilation project.
development_findings.quote: The zoo is actually the reason I even started optimizing Mario 64. The zoo ran so poorly that I just could not take that.

development_findings.summary: The team is working on Course 11, which Kaze considers the 'end game' of the project's development cycle.
development_findings.quote: We're actually just in the end game now for the mod. It didn't feel like it took that long at all to me.

development_findings.summary: A performance optimization related to the 'clip ratio' is causing significant visual artifacts ('melting' geometry) when running on N64 hardware, which is a known but unresolved issue.
development_findings.quote: It's because some triangles are too far away... I think this is because of the clip ratio changes. I still have to figure out what exactly is causing this and if it's worth fixing or not.

development_findings.summary: The retro pipe for Course 11 will be a level based on the 'Board the Platforms' stage from Super Smash Bros. 64.
Kaze decided to completely remake the cannon aiming reticle from scratch because the original was extremely inefficient and was broken by his new custom-written, optimized graphics library.
development_findings.quote: I'm not fixing this. I need a new cannon reticle. To do, let's grab this and make a new cheaper to render cannon reticle, because this is eight matrices and four display lists to render four triangles.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is intentionally designing platforming challenges with multiple solutions, including difficult, high-skill maneuvers like using inertia for shortcuts that reward expert players.
development_findings.quote: If I am a pro player, I can use inertia... Isn't that cool?

development_findings.summary: The concept of a dedicated tutorial level ('dojo') has been scrapped in favor of integrating tutorials into the main game via the bunny characters.
development_findings.quote: A lot of the stuff that we would have taught in the dojo is now being taught by the bunnies.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes game design should empower players with freedom and avoid hand-holding, rejecting features like cannon trajectory guides because they remove skill and decision-making.
context_findings.quote: I think games should be about experiencing freedom. Am I giving you the line to move along? You don't have any freedom. You're just kind of following instructions. I'm not a player. I'm like a guy pushing buttons in a factory.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy includes ensuring visual clarity for all players, acknowledging that if a feature is consistently misunderstood (like the oil color), it's the designer's responsibility to fix it.
context_findings.quote: You have to account for that as a designer. People are going to play your game. And if people are stupid, then you have to account for stupid people playing your game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has permanently switched from streaming on Twitch to YouTube, citing a strong dislike for Twitch's mandatory and unskippable ad system for viewers.
context_findings.quote: I find it personally unwatchable with all the ads. Because on YouTube, at least I can decide whether there's ads or not. I can just say I'm not playing an ad and then there won't be an ad.

context_findings.summary: Kaze follows a high-risk, high-reward development methodology where he intentionally does not test his code to save time, accepting that this will lead to bugs that need to be fixed much later.
context_findings.quote: See that's the thing with me. I never test my code. I just assume it works. And it saves me a lot of time. And usually it does. And sometimes, months later, a bug just occurs.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states the game will not be released this year and is committed to finishing the project completely before its release, rather than rushing it.
context_findings.quote: I want to release the game when it's actually completely finished.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally inserted factual errors into his '37 Physics Improvements' video to try and boost engagement through comments correcting him, but the strategy was not as effective as he had hoped.
context_findings.quote: I intentionally made three or four mistakes in total. I said Mario 64 was the first 3D platform ever. It really wasn't. I hoped people would point that out and comment on it.

biobak.summary: Biobak was responsible for the initial orange/red color palette for the oil, which was later changed because players mistook it for lava.
biobak.quote: The red makes it look like running red ash. That was Biobak's idea. I'm innocent.

biobak.summary: Kaze references a specific 'Biobak pink' color, suggesting Biobak has a distinct color palette or style contribution to the project.

badub.summary: Badub is the composer for the project. The music being used in the stream is from their custom-made 'Coupa's Revenge 2 OST', which includes original work and some Mario remixes.
badub.quote: All of the OST is custom made by Badub. So, it actually is not copyrighted. Well, actually, there are some remixes of Mario songs.

zeina.summary: Zeina is working on animations for the Bowser boss fight, sharing an in-progress walk cycle during the stream for feedback.
zeina.quote: Just for the fun of it, I duplicated the other animation and tried to do it from scratch. This kind of looks like a father playing a lizard with his children.

zeina.summary: Zeina is an active participant in the stream's chat and has a playful, public dynamic with Kaze, but expresses a preference for engaging from the chat rather than being on camera.
zeina.quote: I mean, truth be told, I prefer being in the chat. It's more fun.

zeina.summary: Zeina and Kaze's personal life and work are intertwined; they discuss the logistics of a potential week-long 'crunch' stream for multiplayer development.
zeina.quote: Listen, if you gotta stream all day for a week, at least give me a moment to prepare, so I don't have to cook every day.

key_stories.title: The Zipline Regression Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered that ziplines were broken due to a regression. He traced the problem back to an untested optimization he made to the collision code months ago, found a simple syntax error, and fixed it, viewing the incident as a validation of his time-saving 'develop now, test later' philosophy.
key_stories.challenge: A core gameplay mechanic, ziplines, was discovered to be completely non-functional, halting progress on the level's design.
key_stories.process: Kaze first confirmed the bug was a regression. He then used print-style debugging to trace the code, discovering that the raycast to detect the ceiling was failing. This led him to inspect a specific collision optimization he'd implemented months ago, where he quickly found the error.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze identified a single misplaced bracket in a collision function he had optimized months prior. The fix was simple, reinforcing his belief that his 'no-testing' development style saves more time than it costs, despite occasional bugs.
key_stories.key_quote: I found an optimization with collision... But when I did that, I messed up the code and I actually never tested it. See that's the thing with me. I never test my code.

key_stories.title: The Mario Odyssey Lighting System
key_stories.summary: Inspired by Mario Odyssey, Kaze implemented a new camera-based light source to make Mario more visible in dark environments. The change was a huge aesthetic success, allowing for more dramatic lighting, but it also introduced several new graphical bugs that need to be resolved.
key_stories.challenge: The game's lighting felt dark, making Mario difficult to see and causing scenes to be hard to read.
key_stories.process: After watching Mario Odyssey, Kaze was inspired to add a secondary light source that originates from the camera and only affects moving objects like Mario. He implemented this new lighting system and immediately saw the aesthetic benefits, but also noted the new technical problems it created.
key_stories.outcome: The new lighting system dramatically improved the game's visual appeal, allowing for darker ambient light and deeper shadows while keeping Mario perfectly illuminated. However, this change introduced new bugs, including broken lighting on static objects and major graphical glitches on N64 hardware.
key_stories.key_quote: I was watching Mario Odyssey footage... I changed something about the lighting... I added the light coming from the camera back.

key_stories.title: The Oil Color Change
key_stories.summary: The level's 'oil' was consistently being mistaken for lava, a design flaw Kaze took responsibility for. After live experimentation with colors based on viewer feedback, he changed the palette from red/orange to blue/purple, successfully fixing the issue and improving the level's overall aesthetic.
key_stories.challenge: The liquid in the oil rig level was colored orange and red, causing many viewers to misinterpret it as lava or burning ash, which ruined the intended atmosphere.
key_stories.process: Kaze acknowledged that the visual communication was failing based on stream feedback. He solicited color ideas and experimented live, switching from the original orange/red (an idea from Biobak) to a new blue/purple scheme.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze changed the oil color to a deep blue/purple. The new color was immediately praised for feeling 'more rich' and successfully communicating 'oil' instead of 'lava', resolving the design issue and improving the level's atmosphere.
key_stories.key_quote: Too many people think it's burning ash or lava. So I do see an issue there... You have to account for that as a designer.

open_questions.context: When testing on N64 hardware, the graphics began 'melting.' Kaze attributed this to a 'clip ratio change' he made for performance but noted he has to investigate if it's worth fixing.
questions: Can you explain what the 'clip ratio' optimization is and what performance benefits it provides?
What is your current theory on why it causes these specific graphical glitches on hardware?

open_questions.context: Kaze is writing his own optimized version of libultra, the N64 development library. This was mentioned as the reason the old cannon reticle code was broken.
questions: What motivated you to write your own version of libultra instead of using existing tools?
What are the main goals of this custom library? Is it just for performance, or are there other objectives?
How much of the original library have you replaced, and what have been the biggest challenges?

Zeina, what tools are you using? What are the unique challenges of creating animations for the N64?
